title.narrative: 002 END OPEN DEFECATION

description.narrative: By 2025, communities (Kebeles) in all parts of the country have increased capacity to end open defecation, practice appropriate hygienic behavior (HWWS) and use basic inclusive and gender responsive sanitation services., which contributes to Safe And Equitable Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Services And Practices, Water, Sanitation And Hygiene Systems And Empowerment Of Communities. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Communications, Advocacy And Public Engagement, Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Evaluations, Research And Data, Harnessing Power Of Business And Markets, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Partnerships And Engagement: Public And Private, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 'By 2025 children and their families in rural and urban areas use safe, affordable and sustainable water, sanitation and practice appropriate hygiene

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2025, communities (Kebeles) in all parts of the country have increased capacity to end open defecation, practice appropriatehygienic behavior (HWWS) and use basic inclusive and gender responsive sanitation services.

description.narrative: Aprogramme implementation manual was developed for the Ministries of Water, Education, and Health regarding the roll-out of the national ODF campaign.; The development of aweb-based monitoring platform, including astrategy for behaviour change communication, monitoring and evaluation framework is in progress. Over 2.9 million people in seven regions (Afar, Amhara, BG, Gambella, Oromia, Somali, SNNPR) received key hygiene messages. Menstrual hygiene management in 96 schools is contributing to retention of adolescent girls and potentially contributing to improving school completion rates. A total of 597 communities (2.9m people) have been certified ODF in 6 regions. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:08/01/2022
